data.title: The Best Trade Schools in Georgia – Campus and Online
data.meta_description: Georgia is a great place to earn a diploma or certificate for skilled occupations. Explore the best online and on-campus trade schools in the state!
data.text:
Also called the Empire State of the South, Georgia is a top performer when it comes to economic growth in the United States. The state capital Atlanta is the most populous city where the busiest airport is found. Home to major corporations such as Delta Air Lines, Inc. and The Coca Cola Company, Georgia was named by CNBC as one of America’s best states for business.

The Peach State has 50 colleges and universities, and trade or vocational schools. Students are fortunate to explore post-secondary school options. These quality and affordable colleges offer programs for in-demand fields such as automotive technology, construction, manufacturing, healthcare, and machine technology. According to the Technical College System of Georgia’s “Governor’s High Demand Career Initiative Report,” 60% of jobs will demand some form of degree (technical certificate, associate degree, bachelor’s degree, etc.) by the year 2020. This prompted a partnership between the University System of Georgia and Technical College System of Georgia (TCSG) to broaden student access to post-secondary institutions. Also, TCSG holds Georgia’s Quick Start program, which is designed to provide free customized training needed to match the growing needs of businesses.

Most trade and vocational schools train students in less than two years. These schools allow students to meet with potential employers through Georgia QuickStart. Training for workforce development is free and prioritizes the business’ standards.

With such a blend of convenience and a variety of choices, students in Georgia are guaranteed to find a college that best fits their career goals. But if you’re indecisive, this ranking will help you take the first step.

Home to some of the most excellent trade schools in the country, the State of Georgia offers a wealth of options for prospective students. If you are on the hunt for the most suitable on-campus and online trade school to help you become a competent future professional, our list of the best institutions in the state is just what you need!

Whatever industry you’re interested in becoming a part of, there is a trade school in Georgia that will equip you with the knowledge and skills you need to thrive in it. OnlineSchoolsCenter.com presents your top-rated trade school selections—all of which we picked based on these features:

A curriculum covering the training and courses for acquiring top industry skills,

High retention rates,

Hands-on training that leads to a positive student experience for obtaining the required competencies,

Outstanding faculty credentials,

Financial aid options,

Recognition from accrediting agencies.

See our Methodology page to find out more about ranking details.

Start your search for the best trade school that will fit your needs in Georgia today! Navigate our quick links below:

The Best Overall Campus Trade Schools in Georgia

Georgia has some of the best employers in the fields of healthcare, technology, automotive, manufacturing, and finance. Students who plan to train for high-demand careers may choose to start their journey through trade and vocational schools.

The state has a wide-scale career technical education system ready to cater to its diverse and massive population. Find the best trade school campuses in Georgia on our list below:

Columbus Technical College

Formerly known as the Columbus Area Vocational-Technical School, Columbus Technical College opened its doors in 1961. It began training only 39 students and operated as part of the Muscogee County School District. It was one of the first three technical schools selected by the state to offer engineering-technology programs. Today, the school is proud to have served more than 12,000 students. There are more than 100 programs organized in three divisions— Business & General Studies, Health Sciences & Nursing, and Professional & Technical Services. Students have the opportunity to earn an associate degree, certificate, or diploma. Columbus Technical College is accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on Colleges.

Atlanta Technical College

Atlanta Technical College was founded as Smith-Hughes Vocational School in 1945. It’s a unit of the Technical College System of Georgia (TCSG). The school went through a few relocations and name changes until the 1960s. Atlantic Technical College started its mission with only 24 occupational programs and now continues to deliver career-oriented programs divided into seven fields of interests, such as Arts and Sciences, Business Technologies, Health and Public Safety, Technologies, Industrial, Transportation, and Technologies. From humble beginnings, the college now admits almost 4,000 students a year. Its programs are designed to keep up with the needs of the industry.

Georgia Piedmont Technical College

Located in Clarkston, Georgia, Georgia Piedmont Technical College began as DeKalb Area Vocational School. It had its first class with only 18 students when it opened in 1961. It went through five name changes before it finally got its current name, and now the school has grown into one of the best community colleges in the state. In the previous year, the school enrolled over 3,000 students coming from DeKalb, Newton, and Rockdale counties and mostly from the metro Atlanta area. The school offers associate programs which last 18 to 24 months, diploma, and technical certificate programs with less than a year to complete. Its top five programs include Practical Nursing, Computer Information Systems, Business Management, Early Childhood Education, and Medical Laboratory Technology.

Wiregrass Georgia Technical College

Providing career and technical education to Atkinson, Ben Hill, Berrien, Brooks, Coffee, Cook, Echols, Irwin, Lanier, Lowndes, and Wilcox counties, Wiregrass Georgia Technical College was formed through a merger of East Central Technical College (ECTC) and Valdosta Technical College (VTC). The school began to operate in 2010, but East Central Technical College and Valdosta Technical College were built in the 1960s. Now the school runs four campuses: the Ben Hill-Irwin Campus, Coffee County Campus, Cook County Workforce Development Center, and the Valdosta Campus. Its programs have five division categories, namely Allied Health, Business Education, General Education, Professional Services, and Technical & Industrial. Each program is validated and is guaranteed to fit the needs of the business and industry.

Southern Regional Technical College

Southern Regional Technical College is the result of a merger of two technical colleges— Moultrie Technical College and Southwest Georgia Technical College. The two colleges opened more than 70 years ago and decided to form what is now SRTC in 2015. In the preset, SRTC’s main campus is in Thomasville, Georgia, and its other education centers are in Colquitt, Grady, Mitchell, Tift, Turner, and Worth counties. With more than 155 degree and diploma programs to choose from, Southern Regional Technical College assures its more than 4,600 students hands-on training opportunities for their career goals. SRTC is divided into four schools, namely the School of Business, School of Health Sciences, School of Industrial Technology, and School of Professional Services.

Lincoln Tech

Lincoln Tech is a group of for-profit technical institutions. The company is based in New Jersey and operates several campuses across the country. Its Georgia campus is in Marietta, Atlanta. Lincoln Tech has been teaching courses in installation and servicing of air conditioning and refrigeration equipment since 1946. It added its automotive, culinary, health sciences, spa and cosmetology, and information technology programs as it grew. Programs available at the Marietta campus are Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning, Electrical and Electronic Systems Technology, Medical Assistant Technology, and Medical Assistant. Its 30,000-ft campus features Smart House facility for Electrical and Electronic Systems Technician program, Medical Assisting laboratory, and Energy Audit structure and training simulator for HVAC training.

Georgia Northwestern Technical College

Georgia Northwestern Technical College is the largest educational institution in northwest Georgia. It was established after a merger of Coosa Valley Technical College and Northwestern Technical College in 2008. Coosa Valley Technical College and Northwestern Technical College were both founded in the 1960s. Both colleges offered adult education programs in addition to training opportunities to the residents of nine counties in northwest Georgia. Today, the school provides skills training and workforce development in its five campuses located in Walker, Floyd, Gordon, Polk, and Whitfield-Murray counties. GNTC offers a wide selection leading to a degree, a diploma, and certificate credentials. Its more than 5,800 students explored programs from Accounting to Welding.

Augusta Technical College

In 1966, Augusta Technical College was founded as a result of the merger of Augusta Area Vocational-Technical School and Richmond Area Vocational School. The school initially offered associate of applied technology programs and later added adult education programs. In the present, Augusta Technical College runs four campuses. Aside from the main campus, it operates in Augusta, the school has campuses in Thomson, Waynesboro, and Grovetown. Programs of study are structured in five divisions: Allied Health Sciences and Nursing, Arts and Sciences, Learning Support, and Professional Services, Business, Public Services, and Early Childhood Care/Education, Industrial and Engineering Technology, and Cyber and Digital Education. Its more than 4,000 students are guaranteed with flexible and small-size classes.

South Georgia Technical College

Located in Americus, Georgia, South Georgia Technical College was initially named as South Georgia Trade and Vocational School. It traces its origin as a facility of Airforce training during WWI and WWII. It first opened its door to 75 students in 1948. The first few programs offered were Diesel Mechanics, Aircraft Mechanics, and Aircraft Engine Mechanics, Air Conditioning, Basic Radio Service Communication & Code, Sheet Metal Construction, Upholstery, and Woodworking. Today, Basic Radio Service Communication and Code turned to the Electronics Technology program. The school is one of the only two technical colleges in Georgia that offer on-campus housing. There are over 2,000 students enrolled in its 200 associate degree, diploma, and technical certificate programs.

Oconee Fall Line Technical College

In 2010, Georgia’s legislature approved the merger of Sandersville Technical College with Heart of Georgia Technical College. It was when Oconee Fall Line Technical College was established. This public community college is a part of the Technical College System of Georgia now and admits more than 1,400 students from Bleckley, Dodge, Glascock, Hancock, Jefferson, Laurens, Telfair, Warren, Washington, Wheeler, and Wilkinson counties. The school has two main campuses in Sandersville and Dublin, Georgia. OFTC offers a broad range of programs in popular fields that includes automotive, business, electronics, healthcare, and technology. Oconee Fall Line Technical College is accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on College.

Albany Technical College

Albany Technical College was founded as the Monroe Area Vocational-Technical School in 1961. In 1972, the school established a merger with Albany Area Vocational-Technical School. It serves more than 3,000 students who are residents from the Baker, Calhoun, Clay, Dougherty, Lee, Randolph, and Terrell counties and is a part of the Technical College System of Georgia. Albany Technical College is the only school to provide a full-service Career Development Center on campus, and it guarantees ATC students to graduate with a professional portfolio. Degree and certificate programs are delivered through Business and Healthcare, Construction, Manufacturing and Transportation, Education, Logistics, and Technology divisions.

Savannah Technical College

Savannah Technical College traces its roots back in 1959 when Opportunity School and Harris Area Trade School merged to become Savannah Area Vocational-Technical School. It was then in charge of five counties Chatham, Bryan, Effingham, Liberty, and Long, Georgia. Today, the school continues to provide technical training, continuing and adult education to its more than 3,000 students. Besides Savannah, STC operates three other campuses in Liberty, Effingham, Crossroads, and an education center in Fort Stewart, Georgia. Students can choose degree, certificate, and diploma programs from six divisions, namely Aviation Technology, Business and Professional Services, Economic Development, General Studies, Health Sciences, and Industrial Technology.

Gwinnett Technical College

Established in 1984, Gwinnett Technical College began as Gwinnett Area Technical School. It was built to answer the demand for technological training. It changed its name to follow the other state technical institute members of the Technical College System of Georgia (TCSG). The school operates Lawrenceville and Alpharetta campuses and is one of the largest institutions in Georgia, serving more than 9,000 students. There are at least 150 degrees, certificates, and diplomas in a variety of disciplines such as business, life sciences, computer sciences, public and professional sciences, engineering, and manufacturing design. Gwinnett Technical College is accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools, Commission on Colleges.

West Georgia Technical College

West Georgia Technical College was created following a merger with West Central Technical College in 2008. It is also a unit of the Technical College System of Georgia (TCSG) that promotes student access to technical programs. As the second-largest technical largest, West Georgia Technical College serves over 7,000 students coming from Carroll, Coweta, Douglas, Haralson, Heard, Meriwether, and Troup counties annually. This multi-campus school holds classes for technical education, continuing and adult education. As with other technical schools under TCSG, there is a customized business training offered that is at par with industry standards. Students may choose programs from different areas of study like business, healthcare management, transportation, professional services, maintenance and repair, and more.

Lanier Technical College

Originally named as the Gainesville-Hall County Area Vocational Trade School, Lanier Technical College was chartered in 1964 by the Georgia State Board of Education. The school held its classes in various local schools, churches, and civic buildings during its first year. In addition to its campus in Oakwood, Lanier Tech has four more campuses located in Cumming, Winder, Commerce, and Dawsonville, Georgia. Lanier Tech confers a wide array of associate, certificate of credit, and technical certificate options from Accounting to Wireless Networking Technology. The college provides industry-specific training, workforce development for students of all ages and students support services.

The Best Online Trade Schools in Georgia

On-campus programs give more academic options to students, but Georgia has been maximizing learning opportunities through distance learning for quite some time now. A launching of Georgia Virtual School in 2005 and a senate bill (in 2012) encouraging local school districts to offer online education have made it easier for those looking to complete a degree while working.

We have gathered the best trade schools that provide flexible options favorable to the busy students striving to reach their career goals.

Columbus Technical College

Columbus Technical College began its classes in 1961, with only 39 enrollees. It was initially named the Columbus Area Vocational-Technical School and governed by the Muscogee County School District. The school went through changes and expansion and now trains more than 3,0000 students a year. As one of the many units of the Technical College System of Georgia, Columbus Technical College ensures industry-specific training is provided to its students through its on-campus and online programs. The school offers selected associate, diploma, and certificate programs in business, management, computer, and technical communications. It runs a program called Online Learning for Everyone (OLE’) for students who can manage to work on self-paced web-based courses and CARE CENTER accessible as a support service.

Atlanta Technical College

Atlanta Technical College opened its doors after WWII to provide adult vocational education in northwest Atlanta. It was named as Smith-Hughes Vocational School and offered 24 occupational programs. It then grew to become an area of technical vocational school and changed its name. Today, the school serves more than 3,500 students learning degree, diploma, and certificate programs. Distance learners work on combined synchronous and asynchronous courses and have the opportunity to determine their class attendance. Entirely online and hybrid programs include Accounting, Business Management, Business, and Administrative Technology, Marketing Management, and Paralegal Studies. All online courses are accessed through the Blackboard system.

Southern Regional Technical College

Based in Thomasville, Georgia, Southern Regional Technical College was formed out of a merger of Moultrie Technical College and Southwest Georgia Technical College in 2015. Southwest Georgia Tech was built in 1947 and Moultrie Tech in 1964. These schools had been operating seven campuses (in total) located in Colquitt, Grady, Mitchell, Thomasville, Tift, Turner, and Worth. SRTC continues to run these campuses in the present. Online learners can explore several degrees, diploma, and technical certificate programs offered entirely online. The school delivers these programs through Georgia Virtual Technical Connection (GVTC) and courses with the Blackboard system. Some of the programs are Accounting, Health Information Coding, Medical Front Office Assistant, PC Repair and Network Technician, Human Resource Management Specialist, Microsoft Word Application Professional, and more.

Georgia Northwestern Technical College

Georgia Northwestern Technical College was created when a merger of Coosa Valley Technical College and Northwestern Technical College was approved in 2008. Coosa Valley Technical College had been operating for 46 years, then Northwestern Technical College was built in 1964. Both schools offered technical programs for the residents of northwest Georgia. The school admits almost 6,000 students that include distance learners. GNTC provides a wide variety of both fully online and blended programs, from Accounting to Web Site Design. The school uses the Blackboard management learning system to facilitate web-enhanced, online, and hybrid courses.

Augusta Technical College

Augusta Technical College was first known as the Augusta Area Technical School. It was built after the merger of Augusta Area Vocational-Technical School and Richmond Area Vocational School in 1966. From offering an associate degree of applied technology and only seven diploma programs, Augusta Tech now provides a wide variety of program selections, including distance education programs. Fully online classes at Augusta Tech asynchronous and assignments are due weekly. Some online associate degree programs are provided through the Georgia Virtual Technical Connection (GVTC). Students have the opportunity to pick online diploma and certificate programs through web-enhanced, hybrid, or online with lecture, and 100% online classes.

Albany Technical College

In 1972, two established technical schools, Monroe Area Vocational-Technical School and Albany Area Vocational-Technical School merged to form what is now Albany Technical School. The school has been providing technical education to the residents of seven counties: Baker, Calhoun, Clay, Dougherty, Lee, Randolph, and Terrell, Georgia. This public institution does not only offer lifelong opportunities on campus but also extends it for its online learners. The technical certificate may be earned online within one to three semesters, and courses may be applied for next level credentials. Online students are expected to follow a schedule and log on often to the Blackboard system.

West Georgia Technical College

A part of the Technical College System of Georgia (TCSG), West Georgia Technical College was formed as a result of a merger of West Central Technical College and West Georgia Technical College. TCSG kept the latter’s name and designated Carroll as the administrative campus. Besides Carroll, the school serves six other counties such as Coweta, Douglas, Haralson, Heard, Meriwether, and Troup. As the second-largest technical school in the state, WGTC serves more than 7,000 students enrolled in on-campus and online classes. Its academic offerings include completely online degrees and certificate programs. Students can choose areas of study in Accounting, Fire Science Technology, Business Technology, Medical Coding, Marketing Management, and Business Health Technology.

Lanier Technical College

Lanier Technical College was chartered as the Gainesville-Hall County Area Vocational Trade School and opened its doors in 1966. The school was appointed to provide technical education opportunities to the service areas in Banks, Barrow, Dawson, Forsyth, Hall, Jackson, and Lumpkin counties. Since its founding, LTC has made it a goal to be the premier workforce development in north Georgia. In addition to serving seven campuses, LTC offers 25 distance education programs. Students are expected to check the course schedule to see available courses each semester. Most of its programs are delivered completely online through the Blackboard system.

Southeastern Technical College

Based in Vidalia, Georgia, Southeastern Technical College started its journey as Swainsboro Area Vocational Technical School in 1963. It opened with only four programs, seven employees, and 32 enrollees. It was in charge of serving residents of 20 counties. The school later expanded its facilities and added more technical programs over the years. It has satellite locations in Glennville and Swainsboro. The school also provides associate, diploma, and certificate programs for students who want more flexibility and those who cannot attend campus classes. Online courses run 15 weeks long, just like the traditional on-campus classes. STC is a part of the Technical College System of Georgia.

Coastal Pines Technical College

Located in Waycross, Georgia, Coastal Pines Technical College delivers lifelong educational opportunities to 13 counties in the state. The school was established following a merger of Altamaha Technical College and Okefenokee Technical College in 2014. Altamaha Tech was founded in 1989 and Okefenokee in 1965. Its academic offerings are organized into four areas of study, namely Allied Health, Business and Computer, Professional Services, and Technical and Industrial. Distance learners expect online programs to have the same quality as traditional on-site classes. CPTC offers Accounting, Business Technology, Criminal Justice, Early Childhood Care & Education, and Marketing Management.

The Best Accounting Trade Schools in Georgia – Campus and Online

Bookkeepers, accounting, and auditing clerks play an essential role in the day to day operations of the finance department of businesses. These jobs generally involve the production of financial records and checking their accuracy. Basic math, computer skills in spreadsheets, or accounting software are included in these jobs. According to the Bureau of Labor and Statistics, Bookkeeping, Accounting, and Auditing Clerks earn $40,240 per year and report that job openings for these professions will be plenty. The programs offered by trade schools may be taken either on-campus or online.

Southern Regional Technical College

Established in 2015, Southern Regional Technical College is a unit of the Technical College System of Georgia (TCSG). It was built after a merger of Moultrie Technical College and Southwest Georgia Technical College. Moultrie Tech was founded in 1964 with automotive mechanics, diesel mechanics, machine shop, drafting and design technology, and electronics programs. Southwest Georgia Tech was built in 1947 to provide education to the soldier who wanted to build their career. Today, Southern Regional Technical College serves more than 4,600 students enrolled in more than 155 associate, diploma, and certificate programs. Among these programs is the Accounting Diploma. It consists of 55 hours of basic skill, occupational, and elective courses.

Official Program Name: Accounting

Program Level: Diploma

Learning Format: On-campus/ Online

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, State Grants, Scholarships, Veterans Programs

Georgia Northwestern Technical College

After the approval of the Coosa Valley Technical College and Northwestern Technical College merger in 2009, Georgia Northwestern Technical College was created. It continued to serve nine counties in northwestern Georgia. Both schools were established in the early 1960s to provide adult education. In the present, Georgia Northwestern Technical College is governed by the Technical College System of Georgia (TCSG). The school offers occupational, workforce development and adult education. Among its more than 200 degrees, diploma and certificate programs are the Accounting Diploma. This diploma program requires students to complete 42 minimum credit hours.

Official Program Name: Accounting

Program Level: Diploma

Learning Format: On-campus/ Online

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, State Grants, Scholarships

Other states offer online associate programs in Accounting. If you’re interested, check these out: Best Online Schools for Associate of Accounting Degree Programs

The Best Business Technology Trade Schools in Georgia – Campus and Online

The field of Business Technology helps students launch office careers through a wide variety of technical skills. Offices often require experts in routine clerical and administrative tasks. In this digital age, offices need employees to perform duties that make use of several software programs, word processing applications, and spreadsheet programs. Graduates of Business Technology programs may apply for entry-level positions like Secretaries and Administrative Assistants. The Bureau of Labor and Statistics reported that Secretaries and Administrative Assistants are paid $38,880 per year.

Augusta Technical College

Augusta Technical College was founded in 1961 as Augusta Area Vocational-Technical School. It then merged with Richmond Area Vocational School in 1966. The school initially offered diploma programs and adult education. The school expanded its programs and facilities as the need for technical education grew in its five-county service area. Augusta Tech’s academic selection consists of five fields of study, and the school teaches more than 4,000 students in the present. Diploma program options include Business Technology. The program lets students gain knowledge and skills in a technology-driven work setting. Students may enroll for either on-campus or online classes and are expected to complete 50 credit hours to get the diploma.

Official Program Name: Business Technology

Program Level: Diploma

Learning Format: On-campus/ Online

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, State Grants, Scholarships, Veterans Programs

Georgia Northwestern Technical College

A vital part of the Technical College System of Georgia (TCSG), Georgia Northwestern Technical College is one of the largest technical colleges in the state. It was created as a result of the merger of Coosa Valley Technical College and Northwestern Technical College in 2008. The two technical schools had operated for over 55 years. Today, GNTC caters to almost 6,000 students in nine counties of northwestern Georgia. It serves more than 200 programs leading to associate degree, diploma, or certificate. Its division of business technology offers a certificate program in Microsoft Office Application Specialist. The program teaches microcomputer application software skills and only needs 16 credit hours to complete.

Official Program Name: Microsoft Office Application Specialist

Program Level: Certificate

Learning Format: On-campus/ Online

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, State Grants, Scholarships

Coastal Pines Technical College

Coastal Pines Technical College is a member of the Technical College System of Georgia (TCSG). It was formed out of a merger of Altamaha Technical College and Okefenokee Technical College in 2014. Altamaha Technical College was established in 1989, and Okefenokee Technical College was built in 1965. The former schools offered programs in welding, electronics technology, industrial mechanics and maintenance technology. Today, CPTC caters to more than 3,000 students enrolled in over 130 programs in fields of interest in allied health, business and computer, professional services, and technical and industrial. A diploma program in Business Technology may be completed on-campus or online. The program teaches students the use of word processing, spreadsheet, and presentation software. Students are expected to finish 50 credit hours of basic and occupational courses.

Official Program Name: Business Technology

Program Level: Diploma

Learning Format: On-campus/ Online

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, HOPE Grant, Scholarships, Veterans Assistance

Albany Technical College

Albany Technical College was established following the merger of Monroe Area Vocational-Technical School and Albany Area Vocational-Technical School in 1972. The school serves seven counties in the southwest area of Georgia, such as Baker, Calhoun, Clay, Dougherty, Lee, Randolph, and Terrell. In the present, the school enrolls more than 3,000 students learning to achieve an associate degree, diploma, and certificate. Among its academic offerings is the diploma program in Business Technology. Students are expected to complete 52 hours of courses such as Word Processing Applications, Business Document Proofreading & Editing, and Document Production. They must choose between a Business Administrative Assistant or Medical Administrative Assistant as a specialization.

Official Program Name: Business Technology Diploma

Program Level: Diploma

Learning Format: On-campus/ Online

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, Georgia State Grants, Scholarships

The Best Computer Technician Trade Schools in Georgia – Campus and Online

Technology workers play a critical role in many different companies today. Computer technicians are some of the valued types of tech workers in the digital age. They determine problems through troubleshooting, prevent downtime, and mainly assist customers or other employers with questions about computers. These professionals may also be called computer support specialists. According to the Bureau of Labor and Statistics, the demand for these tech workers is expected to increase by ten percent in the next nine years, and the median average pay per year is $53,470.

Southern Regional Technical College

Southern Regional Technical College was formed after the approval of the merger of Moultrie Technical College and Southwest Georgia Technical College in 2015. Southwest Georgia Technical College was built in 1945 as an answer to the need for technical schools after the war. Moultrie Tech was built in 1964 and offered adult education classes. Today, Southern Regional Technical College is based in Thomasville, Georgia, and caters to more than 4,000 students. Future PC technicians can enroll in their certificate program in PC and Network Technician. The program helps students develop skills essential for PC troubleshooting and repair. It requires only 18 hours to finish.

Official Program Name: PC Repair and Network Technician

Program Level: Certificate

Learning Format: On-campus/ Online

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, State Grants, Scholarships, Veterans Programs

South Georgia Technical College

South Georgia Technical College was previously named as South Georgia Trade and Vocational School and first opened its doors in 1948. It is one of the oldest technical schools in Georgia that offered programs in Diesel Mechanics, Aircraft Mechanics and Aircraft Engine Mechanics, Air Conditioning, Basic Radio Service Communication & Code, Sheet Metal Construction, Upholstery, and Woodworking. In the present, the school is a member of the Technical College System of Georgia. It has expanded its academic selection to serve hands-on training for workforce development business and industry. One of the programs offered on campus and online is the PC Repair and Network Technician certificate. It requires only 18 hours of personal computer troubleshooting and repair courses.

Official Program Name: PC Repair and Network Technician

Program Level: Certificate

Learning Format: On-campus

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, Georgia State Grants, Scholarships

Albany Technical College

Albany Technical College was established as a result of the merger of Monroe Area Vocational-Technical School and Albany Area Vocational-Technical School in 1972. The school was in charge of seven counties in the southwest area of Georgia: Baker, Calhoun, Clay, Dougherty, Lee, Randolph, and Terrell. Today, the school caters to more than 3,000 students learning to pursue associate degrees, diplomas, and certificates. Its Public Safety and Technology division offers a diploma program in computer support specialist. Students are required to accomplish 55 hours of core classes in English and Mathematics, occupational courses such as Computer Concepts, Hardware Install and Maintenance, and Program Design and Development. This program is also offered through Albany Tech’s online learning with the same program requirements. All online programs are accessed through the Blackboard management program.

Official Program Name: Computer Support Specialist

Program Level: Diploma

Learning Format: On-campus and Online

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, Georgia State Grants, Scholarships

To earn an online Associate degree in IT, check this out: Best Online Schools for Associate of Information Technology Degree Programs

The Best Medical Coding Trade Schools in Georgia – Campus and Online

Medical coders fulfill their duties on the financial and technical side of the medical setting. Some of the responsibilities of medical coders include dealing with coding claims for reimbursements, conversion of patients’ information to standardized codes, and insurance billing. BLS reports that medical coders receive $40,350 per year for their median pay, and 11% of growth is expected in the next nine years. Some trade schools offer medical coding programs that last for less than a year and hold online classes.

Southern Regional Technical College

Southern Regional Technical College traces its roots from two technical schools. It came to be as a result of the Moultrie Technical College, built in 1964, and Southwest Georgia Technical College, established in 1945, merged in 2015. The two technical schools have been providing technical and adult education for many years now. SRTC’s administrative campus is in Thomasville, and the school operates seven campuses in southwest Georgia. Its more than 4,000 students explore almost 200 programs, which includes a diploma program in Health Information Coding. The program requires 51 credit hours to finish and equips students with training in diagnostic coding, medical procedural coding, and medical terminology.

Official Program Name: Health Information Coding

Program Level: Diploma

Learning Format: On-campus/ Online

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, State Grants, Scholarships, Veterans Programs

Georgia Northwestern Technical College

Serving nine counties across northwestern Georgia, Georgia Northwestern Technical College was created after the merger of Coosa Valley Technical College and Northwestern Technical College. The histories of these two technical schools date back in the 1960s. Coosa Valley Tech served Rome while Northwestern Tech was based in Walker County. GNTC continued to expand after the merger and now admits more than 5,900 students. Its 200 programs are offered with day, evening, or online classes. Among the programs offered on-site and online is the Health Information Management Coding. The program helps students who want to become medical coders in the future. With a total of 48 credit hours, students complete and receive a diploma.

Official Program Name: Health Information Management Coding

Program Level: Diploma

Learning Format: On-campus/ Online

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, State Grants, Scholarships

Lincoln Tech first offered air conditioning and refrigeration equipment service, followed by automotive technology. The school maintains over 20 campuses across the country and one of which is the Marietta, Georgia site. Lincoln Tech – Marietta runs an on-site Smart House facility and an Energy Audit structure and simulator for Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning students. The certificate program in Air Conditioning, Refrigeration & Heating Technology is offered in both day and evening classes for student’s convenience. The program introduces new HVAC systems that will help preserve the health of the environment. It requires 45.5 semester hours to complete.

Official Program Name: Air Conditioning, Refrigeration & Heating Technology

Program Level: Certificate

Learning Format: On-campus

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, Georgia State Grants, Scholarships

Savannah Technical College

Savannah Technical College was founded as the Savannah Area Vocational-Technical School in 1959. It was established after the merger of The Opportunity School and Harris Area Trade School. In addition to the business education and technical-vocational programs provided by the former schools, Savannah Technical College added adult education. In the present, the school serves nearly 4,000 students in different campus locations and education centers. Among its diploma programs is the Air Conditioning Technology, which provides 51 hours’ worth of courses in air conditioning theory and practical application. Savannah Technical College is recognized by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on Colleges.

Official Program Name: Air Conditioning Technology

Program Level: Diploma

Learning Format: On-campus

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, State Grants, Scholarships, Veterans Benefits

Southern Regional Technical College

Southern Regional Technical College is a public community school and a member of the Technical College System of Georgia. It was formed as a result of the merger of two technical schools named Southwest Georgia Technical College and Moultrie Technical College in 2015. These two schools have been operating for more than 55 years, and now SRTC continues its legacy. The school serves seven counties in southwest Georgia, with Thomasville being the administrative campus. Students looking to train for a trade job in air conditioning repair can enroll at SRTC’s certificate program. The program only takes 20 credit hours of courses consisting of theory and practical application in air conditioning systems.

Official Program Name: Air Conditioning Repair Specialist Technical Certificate of Credit

Program Level: Certificate

Learning Format: On-campus

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, State Grants, Scholarships, Veterans Programs

The Best Machine Tool Technology Trade Schools in Georgia – Campus Only

The rise in manufacturing activity has increased job opportunities. Machine tool technology plays a significant role in facilitating companies and industries in the precise manufacturing of parts, components, or products in their highest qualities. Machinist jobs mainly engage in the fabrication and maintenance of machinery. Some of the tools used are grinders, lathes, and milling machines that help build precision in the production of metal parts. The knowledge needed in this job is mathematics, design, mechanical, computers and electronics. The skills required for this type of work include reading comprehension, critical thinking, active listening, and complex problem-solving. As reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, machinists and tool makers earn $44,950 per year.

South Georgia Technical College

With a history that reaches back 71 years ago, South Georgia Technical College is known to be one of the oldest technical colleges in the state. The school is located in Americus, Georgia, where its grounds were once a training site for U.S. Army Pilots. At the time, it offered only six programs to its 75 students. The programs were Diesel Mechanics, Aircraft Mechanics, and Aircraft Engine Mechanics, Air Conditioning, Basic Radio Service Communication & Code, Sheet Metal Construction, Upholstery, and Woodworking. Today, the school has a myriad of program selections that include health care and personal services, business, industrial, and transportation technologies. A certificate program in CNC Operator equips students with knowledge and skills in the use of basic machine tools and applications. Students need to complete semester courses and machine tool internship.

Official Program Name: CNC Operator

Program Level: Certificate

Learning Format: On-campus

Financial Aid: Federal Direct Loans and Grants, Federal Work-Study Program, Georgia State Grants, Scholarships

Oconee Fall Line Technical College

Oconee Fall Line Technical College is a public community college that operates two primary campuses in Sandersville and Dublin, Georgia. The school was formed after the merger of Sandersville Technical College and Heart of Georgia Technical College that consolidated its resources. OFLTC still offers more than 100 degree programs, diploma programs, and certificate programs for the residents of eleven counties in central and eastern Georgia. Its more than 1,000 students have the opportunity to advance in career preparation. This includes certificate programs like CNC Specialist where students are trained for courses like CNC Mill Manual Programming, CNC Lathe Manual Programming, and CAD/CAM Programming. Students are expected to complete a design and program to be processed on computer-controlled machines.

Program Level: Certificate

Learning Format: On-campus

Savannah Technical College

Savannah Technical College was created as a result of the merger of The Opportunity School and Harris Area Trade School in 1959. The school kept both school’s programs in business education and technical-vocational areas after the merger. Savannah Tech got its current name and grew to serve more students in five county service areas, including Chatham, Bryan, Effingham, Liberty, and Long.
